Description: Farm on a hillside; view of farm buildings and sheds at top, seen from a height, sloping fields at centre and treetops in the foreground Graphite, heightened with white; on blue-grey paper
Curator's comments: Label text (added 2003): The work of Eustache has remained largely unknown. His private fortune combined with its innate modesty meant that he never fell the necessity to sell his paintings or lithographs, with the result that most of his works remained until recently in the possession of his family. He travelled widely, to province, Switzerland, Italy, and, above all, Egypt, where he accompanied Prosper Marilhat, his teacher. After 1857 he retired to Cherbourg where he continued to produce pastels and charcoal drawings of the Normandy countryside as well as seascapes.
Exhibition history: 1996, BM, French Drawings from the BM, (no cat.)
Acquisition notes: This item has an uncertain or incomplete provenance for the years 1933-45. The British Museum welcomes information and assistance in the investigation and clarification of the provenance of all works during that era.
